content.webTitle: View from Hastings on the referendum: ‘We do well out of the EU here – we’re Europeans’

fields.headline: View from Hastings on the referendum: ‘We do well out of the EU here – we’re Europeans’
fields.bodyText: The blaring of trumpets launched the fighting on the Sussex coast 950 years ago, when the Normans began their conquest of England. This weekend, the country’s relationship with continental Europe was again in the balance, and in the town associated with the battle in 1066, the war fronts, albeit less sonorously, were being drawn up among potential voters in the EU referendum on 23 June. “I’m Anglo-Saxon to the core,” said Sussex businessman Paul Johnson, visiting Hastings with his wife Catherine. “Why don’t we learn from history? The Normans took over. I have watched Europe become a monster in my lifetime. Now it’s going to eat the Tory party. It’s a shambles, a dreadful state of affairs. The sooner we get out, the better.” An unscientific straw poll suggested, however, that this is not a majority view. “We’ve seen a lot of east Europeans here,” said Ann Sheldon, a retired music teacher. “A lot have gone already and I’d hate to see more go. I used to think I’d like to get out of the European Union but now I’m not so sure. Hastings does well out of foreign students and the like. I feel a lot more comfortable here on the south coast, where you actually meet a lot of foreign people, than when I lived in Derbyshire, where you met none. I can tell anyone who asks that this hand-out notion is rot. Shame on you David Cameron for that rot. I’m not convinced change is for the better. We’re a bit too small a country to be going it alone; it doesn’t feel like that’s the way the world is nowadays.” Running a flower stall in a cobbled lane lined with independent cafes, Lisa Reeder has made up her mind. “I will vote to stay in. I think we’d lose a lot of foreign trade otherwise. I think it would make it more difficult to keep any illegal immigrants out, if that’s what people are worried about, because the French wouldn’t care so much. I holiday in France and I like being able to just hop on a train and go; it’s nice and easy. I wouldn’t like that to start getting complicated.” “I don’t really know if I’ll vote,” said Louis, the 25-year-old deputy manager of the 1066 Bakery in Hastings town centre. “I have family in Spain and I want to be able to come and go there as much as I want. I think staying in Europe is definitely far better financially for us.” When the Normans defeated King Harold’s army on 14 October 1066, it took one very bloody day to achieve the victory. A few miles from Hastings is Battle Abbey, erected on the site of the battlefield by William the Conqueror, to atone for the bloodshed. Yesterday, Spanish student Marco and his Scottish girlfriend, Amy, both studying in Hastings, were paying a visit. Both are dreading the next four months of tortuous national political sparring. “The thing I dread is that, as with the Scottish referendum, we’re now going to be fed a whole loads of lies and counter-lies. It just makes politicians look like hypocrites,” said Amy. “Look, we’re the generation that counts, and we’re Europeans. We don’t care if Michael Gove lives in the past and still hates the French, we’d love to have Angela Merkel as a leader. Never mind giving 16-year-olds the vote, I think we should take it away from over-65s.” Marco, however, is impressed by the prime minister. “I think to go to Brussels and try and get something for your country is a good thing. I don’t know if what he got is any good or not, but he did do this.” Inside the cafe at the abbey, there is an inscription on a wall from WC Sellar and RJ Yeatman’s humorous book, 1066 and All That. “The Norman conquest was a ‘good thing’. As from this time onwards, England stopped being conquered and thus was able to become ‘top nation’.” Everyone approached by the Observer in Hastings and Battle agreed on one point. “I need to know more,” said Sami Al-Rahman, a cab driver, on his way into the east European supermarket for his favourite pepper sauce. “It’s all to play for and we can’t afford to get it wrong.” Johnson’s wife, Catherine, remarked that without the Norman victory “we wouldn’t have had the Domesday book”. Her husband retorted: “And when did you last enjoy a read of the Domesday book?” She laughed: “Anglo-Saxon to the core? I think all this history is getting him. He’d better not have a look at my family tree!”
